metadata.titleEn: A dataset of human footprint over the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau during 1990–2017
metadata.description:
Since the first Industrial Revolution, human activity has profoundly affected all spheres of the earth, and this influence will continue to expand and intensify. As an ecosystem unit with global significance, the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP) is also an important ecological security barrier in China, playing a crucial role in soil and water conservation, biodiversity conservation, water conservation and carbon balance. However, in the past 30 years, with the expansion of the scope and rapid growth of the intensity of human activities on the QTP, a series of ecological and environmental issues caused by human activities have become increasingly prominent and seriously affected the ecological functions of the QTP. The comprehensive spatial dataset that records human activity intensity will contribute to a deeper understanding of the intensity and scope of human activities in the region, reveal the law of change of human activities in the context of climate warming, and have important significance for further quantitative identification of the impact of human activities and climate change on the ecosystem, as well as promoting the sustainable development of the region.
In this study, the human footprint index method was adopted to evaluate the intensity of human activity on the QTP, which used six types of spatial data as indicators of human activities, including population density, land use, grazing density, night lighting, railway and road. The dataset records indicators of human activity intensity in the seven phases, namely, 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015 and 2017.  The optimization and adjustment of the human footprint method in this dataset mainly include: (1) Six kinds of data including population density, land use, night lighting, grazing density, road and railway were selected to calculate the intensity of human activities; (2) Adjust the assignment of different land use types; (3) The maximum intensity threshold of population density was set at 50 people/km2, and the logarithmic method was used to assign the value. (4) The cattle and sheep density data were used to characterize the grazing density, and the maximum intensity threshold was set as 1000 sheep units/km2, and the logarithmic method was used to assign the value. (5) The corrected DMSP/OLS night lighting data were used for assigning values; (6) Divide the road into five grades, namely expressway, national road, provincial road, county road and other roads, and assign values respectively; (7) The maximum influence range of railway is set as 3.5km; (8) Using glacier and lake spatial data for quality control .
The dataset contains the data from "Duan, Q., & Luo, L. (2020). A dataset of human footprint over the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau during 1990–2015. China Scientific Data, 5(3). https://doi.org/10.11922/csdata.2019.0082.zh", and the newly produced data of 2017.
This dataset can provide spatial data for exploring the characteristics and rules of spatial changes of human activities in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, and can also provide support for exploring the interaction between human activities and ecological environment in the region. it can play a guiding role in promoting the ecological environment protection and sustainable development of the entire Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.
metadata.instructions: This dataset includes human footprints data products for six time periods in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, stored as a compressed file named “A dataset of human footprint over the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau during 1990–2017.zip”. It consists of seven GeoTIFF files named after the respective years, and the data projection is Krasovsky_1940_Albers. the data can be read and edited by common GIS and remote sensing software such as ArcGIS, QGIS, ENVI and ERDAS.

background: The Qinghai-Tibet Plateau is a distinct natural and cultural landscape unit on Earth with a relatively fragile ecological environment. Over the past 30 years, as human activities have continuously increased their impact on the ecosystem of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, the preparation of spatial datasets on human activity intensity has become essential for a deeper understanding of the ecological and environmental effects of human activities in the region. Accurate evaluation of human activity intensity is the foundation for exploring the ecological and environmental effects of human activities on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau and plays an important role in promoting ecological environmental protection and sustainable development in the region. Currently, the evaluation of human activity intensity mainly relies on statistical analysis methods, making it difficult to generate high-quality spatial data on human activity intensity. Compared to the rapid development of research methods, preparation speed, spatio-temporal resolution, and data quality related to climate change research in recent decades, spatial data related to human activities is still in an exploratory development stage. The human footprint index method, as a method for preparing spatial data on human activity intensity, has been applied and developed at various scales globally since it was proposed by Sanderson et al. in 2002.
research objective: In this study, the human footprint index method was adopted to evaluate the intensity of human activity on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, which used six types of spatial data as indicators of human activities, including population density, land use, grazing density, night lighting, railway, and road.
methods: The dataset records indicators of human activity intensity in the six phases, namely, 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010, and 2015. In this study, the human footprint index method was adopted to evaluate the intensity of human activity on the QTP, which used six types of spatial data as indicators of human activities, including population density, land use, grazing density, night lighting, railway, and road.
dataset: This dataset includes human footprints data products for six time periods in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, stored as a compressed file named “A dataset of human footprint over the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau during 1990–2015.zip”. It consists of six TIFF files named after the respective years, with a total data volume of 53.9 MB.

background: Alpine ecosystems, which account for only 3% of the world’s land area, are fragile and extremely sensitive to global climate change and human activities. Natural and anthropogenic interferences are key to the development of alpine ecosystem spatiotemporal heterogeneity and affect the composition and functioning of alpine ecosystems. Although recent climate change has primarily contributed to alpine environmental change, human activities also exert important impacts. The alpine ecosystem on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau (QTP) has undergone universal and significant warming in recent decades, and the rate of warming is approximately twice the global average from 1960 to 2009. Temperature and moisture are considered the two key factors driving the formation and development of alpine vegetation. Previous studies have shown that human activities also cause major disturbances to alpine ecosystems. Increasing human activities, such as increases in human population, land cover and land use change, grazing pressure and engineering construction, have profoundly intensified the threats to alpine ecosystems. The central area of the QTP is its most populated area and is a critical engineering and transportation corridor that connects inland China and the QTP. The QTR is considered a landmark project, as it was the first time in history that railway transport from Golmud in Qinghai Province to Lhasa of the Tibet Autonomous Region had been introduced. The QTR has alleviated traffic bottlenecks that hinder the economic and social development of the QTP. The alpine ecosystem in the QTEC is extremely sensitive to climate change and human disturbance. It is therefore critical to determine how the alpine ecosystem of the QTEC responds to the joint influences of climate and human activities. Related research in this area has mainly focused on alpine vegetation responses to climate change, while human activities, especially the influence of the QTR, have seldom been addressed.
research objective: To assess how distance from the railway and different regions has influenced the impact of the QTR on the alpine ecosystem, human footprint maps were produced to indicate human pressures, and the normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI), an index of vegetation greenness, was used to characterize the growth of alpine vegetation. To obtain more insights into the ecological effects of the QTR on the alpine ecosystem in the QTEC, the QTR was used as a trigger factor to investigate long-term vegetation responses to climate and human activities in the QTEC.
challenges: At present, the main problem associated with the grassland restoration project is that the subsidy for the project in Tibet is less than 5000 yuan per capita per year, which is lower than the annual grazing income of herdsmen and thus affects the enthusiasm of herdsmen to participate in the project. Although the warmer and wetter climatic trend observed over the course of this study has proven beneficial for enhancing alpine vegetation greenness, the declining trend of alpine vegetation greenness has tended to be stronger in regions with stronger human pressures.
dataset: Weather station data from the area surrounding the QTEC were obtained from the China Meteorological Administration (CMA,http://data.cma.cn). The Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (A VHRR) developed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) was used to generate the third-generation Global Inventory Modelling and Mapping Studies (GIMMS 3g) NDVI dataset. Data on human pressures, including land use/cover, night-time light, population density, grazing density and road and railway distributions, were collected to generate human footprint maps of the QTEC for 2001 and 2015 at a 1-km resolution.
findings: The construction and operation of the QTR have increased human pressures, while the establishment of nature reserves has effectively reduced human pressures. The QTR contributes significantly to the increased human pressures in the Tibetan region compared with the Qinghai region and exerts negative impacts on alpine vegetation. Although the warmer and wetter climate trend has proven beneficial in enhancing alpine vegetation greenness, the declining trend of alpine vegetation has been stronger in regions with more intensive human pressures, especially in the grazing areas and the tourist areas around Lhasa. These results suggest that the impact of the QTR on alpine vegetation in Tibet is greater than that in Qinghai and that the spatial extent of the indirect impact of the QTR in Tibet is confined to approximately 30 km from the railway.

Verification.Question: Are night lighting data used to assess human activity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau dataset?

Concept Completion.Question: Where can data on human pressures, like land use and population density, be collected to create human footprint maps for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Concept Completion.Answer: land use/cover records, night-time light data, population density statistics, grazing density records, road and railway distributions

Concept Completion.Question: What challenges are associated with generating high-quality spatial data on human activity intensity for regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how human activity intensity is evaluated using spatial data indicators on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Example.Answer: Human activity intensity on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau is evaluated using the human footprint index method, which incorporates six types of spatial data indicators: population density, land use, grazing density, night lighting, railway, and road data.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that records human activity intensity over multiple time periods in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset includes human footprints data products for six time periods (1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010, and 2015) in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, stored as a compressed file with TIFF files named after the respective years.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the human footprint index method used to evaluate human activity intensity?
Feature Specification.Answer: population density, land use, grazing density, night lighting, railway, road, thresholds for population density, thresholds for grazing density, corrected night lighting data, different values for various road types

Feature Specification.Question: What specific attributes are used to calculate human activity intensity on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: population density, land use, grazing density, night lighting, transportation data

Feature Specification.Question: What are the methods used to control data quality in the human footprint datasets for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: glacier and lake spatial data, threshold settings for population density, threshold settings for grazing density, adjustments to night lighting data

Quantification.Question: What is the maximum intensity threshold set for population density in the data collection method?
Over how many time periods is the human footprint data collected for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?

Definition.Question: What is the 'human footprint index method' in the context of evaluating human activity intensity on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Definition.Answer: The human footprint index method is a research approach used to evaluate the intensity of human activity on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau by utilizing six types of spatial data as indicators of human activities, including population density, land use, grazing density, night lighting, railway, and road.

Definition.Question: How is 'grazing density' represented in the context of human activity data collection on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Definition.Answer: In the context of human activity data collection on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, grazing density is represented using cow and sheep density data, with a maximum intensity threshold set at 1000 sheep units per square kilometer, and values are assigned using a logarithmic method.

Definition.Question: What does 'night-time light data' represent in the evaluation of human activities on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Definition.Answer: In the evaluation of human activities on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, night-time light data represents the intensity of human activities, and it is assigned values using corrected DMSP/OLS nighttime light data.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using the human footprint index compare to those using the normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) for assessing human impact on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: The human footprint index method evaluates human activity intensity by using six types of spatial data, including population density, land use, grazing density, night lighting, railway, and road. In contrast, the NDVI method assesses vegetation greenness to characterize the growth of alpine vegetation, and it was used alongside human footprint maps to understand the ecological effects of human activities.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data sources and resolution between human footprint maps created for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau and datasets used for global climate change research?
Comparison.Answer: Human footprint maps for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau utilize spatial data such as population density, land use, night-time light, grazing density, and transportation networks, focusing on regional specifics. In contrast, global climate change research datasets tend to have higher preparation speed, better spatio-temporal resolution, and data quality, indicating a more advanced development stage compared to human activity spatial data.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of generating high-quality spatial data on human activity intensity differ from those encountered in evaluating climate change impacts on alpine ecosystems?
Comparison.Answer: Generating high-quality spatial data on human activity intensity is challenging due to reliance on statistical analysis methods, which may not provide the desired resolution or quality. In contrast, evaluating climate change impacts on alpine ecosystems is primarily challenged by the need to integrate and analyze complex interactions between natural and human-induced changes, such as temperature, moisture, and human activities, including infrastructure development.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the need for high-quality spatial data on human activity intensity in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: High-quality spatial data on human activity intensity is needed to accurately explore the ecological and environmental effects of human activities on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, which is critical for promoting ecological environmental protection and sustainable development in the region.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the effects of incorporating corrected night-time light data on the accuracy and quality of human activity intensity datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating corrected night-time light data can enhance the accuracy and quality of human activity intensity datasets by providing a more precise representation of human presence and activities, leading to better assessments of ecological impacts and more informed decision-making for conservation and development strategies.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to generate spatial datasets on human activity intensity for regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Generating spatial datasets on human activity intensity is necessary for a deeper understanding of how human activities impact the ecosystem of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. This understanding is crucial for exploring the ecological and environmental effects of human activities and for supporting sustainable development and ecological protection efforts in the region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can population density, land use, and grazing density data be integrated to create a comprehensive human activity intensity map for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To create a comprehensive human activity intensity map, researchers use the human footprint index method, incorporating six types of spatial data: population density, land use, grazing density, night lighting, railway, and road. This involves selecting relevant datasets, setting maximum intensity thresholds, and applying logarithmic scaling for specific variables like population and grazing density.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are necessary to adjust and optimize the human footprint index for the unique ecological characteristics of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Adjusting the human footprint index for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau involves selecting appropriate data types such as population density, land use, and grazing density, and setting specific thresholds, for example, a maximum intensity of 50 people per square kilometer for population density and 1000 sheep units per square kilometer for grazing density. Additionally, the dataset requires the use of corrected DMSP/OLS night-time light data and classification of roads into different categories for accurate representation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific steps are involved in conducting quality control for datasets that include human activity indicators like roads and railways in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Conducting quality control for datasets involving human activity indicators, such as roads and railways, includes using spatial data from glaciers and lakes to verify accuracy, setting the maximum impact range of railways (e.g., 3.5 km), and dividing roads into categories like highways, national, provincial, county roads, and other roads, each with separate values to ensure the dataset accurately reflects human activity intensity.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the creation of spatial datasets on human activity intensity on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The human footprint index method is used to create spatial datasets on human activity intensity, utilizing six types of spatial data: population density, land use, grazing density, night lighting, railway, and road data.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of different data types such as night-time light, population density, and land use contribute to understanding the human impact on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Integrating data types like night-time light, population density, and land use helps in calculating human activity intensity, revealing the spatial extent and intensity of human impacts, and supporting the evaluation of ecological and environmental effects on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or factors facilitate the production of human footprint maps to assess human pressures in alpine ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The production of human footprint maps is facilitated by collecting data on human pressures, including land use/cover, night-time light, population density, grazing density, and road and railway distributions, enabling the assessment of human pressures and their ecological impacts in alpine ecosystems.

Expectation.Question: Why might the human footprint index method not fully capture the complexity of human activity impacts on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The human footprint index method primarily relies on six types of spatial data, which might not fully encapsulate other nuanced variables and interactions that contribute to the complexity of human activity impacts on the ecosystem of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

Expectation.Question: In what ways might the current methods for assessing human activity intensity on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau be insufficient for future ecological and environmental studies?
Expectation.Answer: Current methods may be insufficient due to their reliance on limited indicators, such as population density and night lighting, which may not adequately reflect emerging patterns of human influence or account for indirect and long-term ecological impacts. This could hinder comprehensive understanding and management of ecological and environmental shifts.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of using the human footprint index method for assessing human activity intensity on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The human footprint index method is a valuable approach for assessing human activity intensity on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau as it leverages multiple spatial data indicators, such as population density, land use, and night lighting. This method allows for a comprehensive evaluation of human impacts, which is crucial for understanding ecological and environmental effects. However, the method's effectiveness relies on the quality and accuracy of the input data, and there is room for further refinement to improve spatial resolution and data quality.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how spatial data related to human activities are prepared and what indicators are typically used to measure human activity intensity.
Assertion.Answer: The spatial data on human activity intensity are prepared using the human footprint index method, which utilizes six types of spatial data as indicators of human activities: population density, land use, grazing density, night lighting, railway, and road.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges involved in creating high-quality spatial data on human activity intensity for fragile ecosystems like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: The main challenge in creating high-quality spatial data on human activity intensity is the reliance on statistical analysis methods, which makes it difficult to generate spatial data with the necessary resolution and quality. Additionally, the preparation of datasets related to human activities is in an exploratory development stage compared to climate change research.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection techniques used to evaluate human activity intensity on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, emphasizing the different types of spatial data and their respective roles.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques for evaluating human activity intensity on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau involve the use of human footprint index methods. These techniques incorporate six types of spatial data: population density, land use, grazing density, night lighting, railway, and road data. Each type of data serves as an indicator of human activities, contributing to the calculation of human activity intensity over different time periods.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose strategies for expanding or refining datasets on human activity and ecological interactions in alpine ecosystems, particularly in the context of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: To expand or refine datasets on human activity and ecological interactions in alpine ecosystems, one strategy could be to integrate additional environmental and socio-economic data layers, such as climate variables and economic activities. Implementing higher-resolution remote sensing technologies and incorporating dynamic modeling approaches could provide more detailed insights into temporal and spatial changes. Collaborative data sharing with international research networks could also enhance dataset comprehensiveness and applicability.
